Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Collective Design through Remixing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is set in the context of open innovation communities in which people design physical products that may be based in part on previously contributed designs, exploring how creativity could be enhanced in these communities by presenting the right related designs to an inventor at the right time in order to inspire a creative remixing. 3D printing online communities allow makers, designers characterized as expert amateurs, to share, modify, combine, and print each other's designs. These communities present an opportunity to understand and improve collective design, a form of cumulative innovation. Improvements to innovative processes will contribute to the growth of the economy, and design is an activity that is educationally appealing to many different age groups, demographics, and academic interests.

This research will analyze an existing open innovation community. From data gathered, tools will be built that suggest designs that when combined are more likely to result in an impactful invention. These tools will consider a wide range of possible innovations, suggesting areas of the design space that may lead to fruitful discoveries. Because collective design depends on the varied expertise of its participants, the project brings together makers with professional engineers, architects, and fabricators through an innovation contest. The makers bring energy, diversity, and experience with online collaborative design processes. The professionals bring detailed knowledge of practical problems, as well as an understanding of modeling and simulation technology in relation to materials used in additive manufacturing. The primary method is experimental, informed by the analysis of existing online communities, and testing the new creativity support tools that will be developed. The envisioned tools will analyze the products and social networks of remix communities in order to suggest candidate designs for modification or recombination. Long-held theories about innovation processes will be tested in a new context, potentially leading to new insights concerning collective innovation that will be instantiated in new tools and systems. Data will be gathered, a system will be built, experiments will be run, a contest will be hosted, and the accumulated learning, data, and software will be made available to other interested researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied how a large set of individuals can engage in design processes that generate novel and practical artifacts. In particular, this work focused on remixing, a process through which an individual can take the designs of others, modifying and recombining those designs to create something new. While many forms of design are conducted privately, with small teams competing to find solutions to pressing problems, in the remixing process designers can see all the designs that have come before, and especially designs that have been created recently. They can take these designs and quickly modify them, recontributing them so that others can build on them. The research has shown that designers who use remixing systems are aware of the context of their inventions, and that they work to contribute both novel and practical contributions based on their awareness of what has gone before. Whereas previous research on creativity emphasizes a tradeoff between novelty and practicality, in the context of collective innovation where past designs are visible, designers can gauge what is novel and what is useful simultaneously, leading to the fast evolution of innovative designs. This work involved creating methods to measure the novelty of designs at the point they were created. The work contributes to theories of design and creativity, as well as to theories of computer supported work and information systems. 

The findings have been incorporated into courses attended by professional students who engage in a variety of design fields, including engineering, computer design, architecture, and aerospace. More generally, the work addresses how technologies can complement human design processes. By providing repositories for designs, and mechanisms for finding and modifying designs, technology can help augment human design skills, as part of a process of sharing previous work that can lead to new contributions in a fast cycle of innovation. Design is a process that affects the environment we live in; the environment then affects others, and is passed down to others. Tools that increase the rate of innovation and broaden the number of people who engage in design may have long term effects on our economy and our built environment.
